results.title: 'Screen It' 2014 - Winners
results.brief_description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2014 budding young film and game-makers took up the challenge of creating their own short film or game in response to the theme ‘Reflection.’

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2014 Screen It competition!

results.title: Time Machine [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Werner van Niekerk, Cameron Cockrell and Tea Tree Gully Primary School
results.brief_description: ‘Time Machine’ is about robots that take over the world but there is a scientist that builds a robot that will take back the world. So it is your job to get past the boss. When you get past the boss you get a high score and the minions will try to kill you so watch out and have fun. There are bouncing pads that can help you jump higher and get things like health and score and save you too. There is also health which goes down when you are hit by evil robots or fireballs. Health packs increase your health.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Werner van Niekerk, Cameron Cockrell and Tea Tree Gully Primary School

results.title: Sky's Adventure [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Willow McFadzean, Parker Arnel and Hurstbridge Primary School
results.brief_description: ‘Sky’s Adventure’ is about a girl Sky and a mean girl Britney. Britney was never nice to anyone but she has to reflect on that when Sky says something to her. Will Britney change after reflecting on what she’s done or keep doing it?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Willow McFadzean, Parker Arnel and Hurstbridge Primary School

results.title: Project Vena Cava [game trailer]
results.brief_description: ‘Project Vena Cava’ is an ambitious atmospheric first-person shooter with dark cinematic elements. Its storyline is science fiction themed and is delivered primarily through written documents found throughout the game, as well as a voiceover that accompanies the player throughout. It is similar in style to other sci-fi first-person shooters such as ‘Halo’, ‘Metroid Prime’ and ‘Portal’.

results.title: La Mia Vita = My Life
results.brief_description: An elderly Italian man decides to look through his photo album. This causes him to reflect on his life. From his youth, to his adolescence, through to his older years, the man looks back on the moments of his life that he treasures the most, and those that are very dear to his heart.

results.title: Ignatius Quince: the cautionary tale of a Child Genius
results.brief_description: Every year the school held a science fair. Ignatius Quince, being the child genius he was, had won it for the last 5 years. This year was to be no exception. Ignatius Quince was going to build the most stupendous experiment. However plans don’t always run smoothly and Ignatius Quince gets a hand from a most unexpected person, Mable Syrup.
results.title_for_label: Ignatius Quince: the cautionary tale of a Child Genius

results.title: The Devoted Friend
results.brief_description: This open ended Oscar Wilde tale challenges us to consider whether a bully is aware that they are a bully. It questions whether you can expect a bully to reform by asking them to reflect on their actions. The story shifts focus from the question “what is a bully?” to “what is a true friend?”.
results.description: This open ended Oscar Wilde tale challenges us to consider whether a bully is aware that they are a bully. It questions whether you can expect a bully to reform by asking them to reflect on their actions. The story shifts focus from the question “what is a bully?” to “what is a true friend?”.

results.title: 'Screen It' 2012 - winners
results.brief_description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2012, the theme, ‘Belonging’, attracted around 400 entries.

Nine winning entries were selected across the categories of live action, animation, computer game and a special section, titled “Bullying: no way”. While some films are about fitting in, many of them advocate embracing your unique identity and subsequently being accepted by others.

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2012 Screen It competition!
